sen.j: 幸子女王（ゆきこじょおう、延宝8年9月23日 (旧暦)（1680年11月14日） - 享保5年2月10日 (旧暦)（1720年3月18日））は、江戸時代の日本の皇族。
sen.e: Yukiko Joo (November 14, 1680-March 18, 1720) was a Japanese Imperial family in the Edo period.
Princess Yukiko (November 14, 1680-March 18, 1720) was a member of the Japanese Imperial family in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: Joo→Princessに訂正しました。A member of及び、Japaneseの前にｔheを追加しました。
sen.e: Princess Yukiko (November 14, 1680-March 18, 1720) was a member of the Japanese Imperial family in the Edo period.
Chugu (Palace of the Empress) of the Emperor Higashiyama.
She was given the position "Chugu" (the empress) of the Emperor Higashiyama.
sen.cmt: She was given the position "Chugu" (the empress)に訂正しました。
sen.e: She was given the position "Chugu" (the empress) of the Emperor Higashiyama.

sen.j: 女院号は承秋門院（しょうしゅうもんいん）。
sen.e: Her nyoingo was Shoshumonin.
Her "nyoingo" (the title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Shoshumonin.
sen.cmt: nyoingoの定訳を追加しました。
sen.e: Her "nyoingo" (the title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Shoshumonin.
Her childhood name was 英宮.
Her childhood name was 英宮.
Her childhood name was 英宮.

sen.j: 有栖川宮幸仁親王の第一王女。
sen.e: The first princess of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Yukihito.
She was the first princess of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Yukihito.
She was the first princess of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Yukihito.

sen.j: 有栖川宮正仁親王は異母弟。
sen.e: Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Tadahito was her younger paternal brother.
Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Tadahito was her younger paternal brother.
sen.cmt: Arisugawanomiyaの位置を移動しました。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Tadahito was her younger paternal brother.

sen.j: 元禄10年（1697年）2月25日、東山天皇に入内し、女御宣下を受ける。
sen.e: On February 25, 1697, she married the Emperor Higashiyama and received the Imperial letter of appointment as Nyogo.
On February 25, 1697, she married the Emperor Higashiyama, and received the Imperial letter of appointment as the title Nyogo.
sen.cmt: As Nyogo→as the title Nyogoに訂正しました。
sen.e: On February 25, 1697, she married the Emperor Higashiyama, and received the Imperial letter of appointment as the title Nyogo.

sen.j: 元禄13年（1700年）、第一皇女・秋子内親王（のちの伏見宮貞建親王妃）を出産。
sen.e: In 1700, she gave birth to the first Princess Imperial Princess Shushi (Akiko) (later the wife of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadataka).
In 1700, she gave birth to the first daughter, Imperial Princess Shushi (Akiko), who became the wife of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadataka later.
sen.cmt: the first Princess→the first daugther, ()をとり、who becameを追加しました。
sen.e: In 1700, she gave birth to the first daughter, Imperial Princess Shushi (Akiko), who became the wife of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadataka later.

sen.j: 宝永4年（1707年）5月3日に准后宣下を経て、翌宝永5年（1708年）2月27日、中宮に冊立される。
sen.e: She received Imperial letter of appointment as Jugo on May 3, 1707, and formally became a chugu on February 27, 1708.
sen.cmt: 「准后宣下」は定訳不明ですが、「女御宣下」の訳を参考にしました。
sen.e: She received the Imperial letter of appointment as the title Jugo on May 3, 1707; She was given the title Chugu on February 27, 1708.
sen.cmt: Imperial の前にtheを追加。Jugoの前にthe titleを追加。, and を; she wasに変更。Formally became a chuguをwas given the title Chuguに訂正しました。
sen.e: She received the Imperial letter of appointment as the title Jugo on May 3, 1707; She was given the title Chugu on February 27, 1708.

sen.j: この結婚は４代征夷大将軍徳川家綱の斡旋で行われたもので、江戸幕府は中務省本多忠国らを派遣して賀辞を奏している。
sen.e: This marriage was arranged by Ietsuna TOKUGAWA, the fourth Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) sent Tadakuni HONDA of the Ministry of Central Affairs to celebrate their marriage.

This marriage had been arranged by Ietsuna TOKUGAWA, the fourth Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") so that some officers, such as Tadakuni HONDA of the Ministry of Central Affairs were sent from the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to celebrate the marriage.
sen.cmt: This marriage wasをThis marriage had beenに訂正。so thatを追加。Some officers, such asを追加しました。
sen.e: This marriage had been arranged by Ietsuna TOKUGAWA, the fourth Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") so that some officers, such as Tadakuni HONDA of the Ministry of Central Affairs were sent from the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to celebrate the marriage.

sen.j: 宝永6年（1709年）6月、東山天皇が譲位し、自身の養子となっていた中御門天皇が践祚。
sen.e: In June 1709, the Emperor Higashiyama abdicated the throne to his adopted child, the Emperor Nakamikado, who ascended to the throne.
The Emperor Higashiyama abdicated the throne to his adopted child in June 1709 when the child ascended to the throne and became the Emperor Nakamikado.
sen.cmt: 語順を変え、when, becameを追加しました。
sen.e: The Emperor Higashiyama abdicated the throne to his adopted child in June 1709 when the child ascended to the throne and became the Emperor Nakamikado.

sen.j: 同年12月に東山上皇が崩御すると、翌宝永7年（1710年）3月21日に女院号宣下を受け、間もなく出家する。
sen.e: When the retired Emperor Higashiyama died in December the same year, Yukiko Joo received the imperial proclamation for nyoingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) on March 21, 1710 and soon entered into priesthood.

Once the retired Emperor Higashiyama died in December of the same year, Princess Yukiko received the imperial proclamation for "nyoingo" (the title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) on March 21, 1710; She became a Buddhist nun soon after that.
sen.cmt: When→Onceに訂正。The same yearの前にofを追加。and soon entered into priesthoodをshe became a nun soon after thatに訂正しました。
sen.e: Once the retired Emperor Higashiyama died in December of the same year, Princess Yukiko received the imperial proclamation for "nyoingo" (the title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) on March 21, 1710; She became a Buddhist nun soon after that.

sen.j: 享保5年2月10日（1720年3月18日）に没。
sen.e: Died on March 18, 1720.
Princess Yukiko died on March 18, 1720.
Princess Yukiko died on March 18, 1720.
Died at the age of 41.
She died at the age of 41.
She died at the age of 41.

sen.j: 陵所は京都府京都市東山区の月輪陵。
sen.e: Her mausoleum is located at Tsukinowa no misasagi (the Tsukinowa Mausoleum) in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Her mausoleum is located at Tsukinowa no misasagi (the Tsukinowa Mausoleum) in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Her mausoleum is located at Tsukinowa no misasagi (the Tsukinowa Mausoleum) in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
